docs.lead_paragraph: The AT&T Corporation agreed on Tuesday to sell its over-the-phone language interpretation service to an affiliate of Providence Equity Partners Inc., a private investment firm. The price was not disclosed. The business, AT&T Language Line, has annual revenue of more than $70 million and interprets 140 languages. It provides its services to insurance, health care, financial and utility companies, as well as law enforcement, emergency services and government agencies in the United States and Canada.

headline.main: AT&T to Sell Language Interpretation Unit

docs.abstract: AT&T Corp to sell AT&T Language Line, over-the-phone language interpretation service, to Providence Equity Partners Inc affiliate; Chris Ensign, general manager, will become president of business, which interprets 140 languages (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stephen J. Sabbeth, who was convicted of Federal bankruptcy fraud earlier this month, is preparing to step down as chairman of the Nassau County Democratic Party, officials here and in Albany said today. Mr. Sabbeth is expected to be succeeded as party chairman by State Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli, said party workers close to Mr. Sabbeth. Mr. DiNapoli said this afternoon that he was ''very willing to take on the job.''

headline.main: Nassau Democratic Leader Is Expected to Step Down

docs.abstract: Stephen J Sabbeth, who was convicted of Federal bankruptcy fraud earlier this month, is preparing to step down as chairman of Nassau County Democratic Party; Sabbeth is expected to be succeeded by State Assemblyman Thomas P DiNapoli; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The new era of Federal surpluses was supposed to change the tired dynamics of budget battles in Washington. That was because there really is enough money to enact some tax cuts, some new spending and some help for Social Security and Medicare. For now, however, the Republican Congressional leadership appears to prefer radical tax and spending cuts to reasoned accommodation on the budget. The House and Senate budget committees are pushing similar plans that call for excessive tax cuts and spending reductions while leaving Medicare's problems unaddressed. Even many Republicans fear that the party's budget schemes are unwise and unrealistic. They and like-minded Democrats should reject the budget plans when they come to a vote on the House and Senate floors this week.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that Republican Congressional leadership appears to prefer radical tax and spending cuts to reasoned accomodation on budget; maintains that House and Senate budget committees are pushing similar plans that call for excessive tax cuts and spending reductions while leaving Medicare's problems unaddressed; urges lawmakers to reject budget plans when they come to vote

docs.lead_paragraph: YOU have just had a long meal at Tabla -- three courses and plenty of wine. When it's time to leave, you are feeling fine. Until you reach the staircase.

headline.main: It's Scary at the Top: Vertigo as Restaurant Trend

docs.abstract: Vertiginous staircases are an increasing feature of New York restaurants, where second-floor dining room has become commonplace in restrauteur's quest for space; photo of sweeping staircase at Tabla (M)
docs.snippet: YOU have just had a long meal at Tabla -- three courses and plenty of wine. When it's time to leave, you are feeling fine.    Until you reach the staircase.

docs.lead_paragraph: The judge overseeing the liquidation of the HIP Health Plans of New Jersey said today that nearly 25 percent of the bankrupt plan's members had yet to find new coverage and that as a result he would consider ''a limited extension'' of the enrollment period. The judge, Jack L. Lintner of Middlesex County Superior Court, said that he would hold hearings next Tuesday to determine whether he should extend the enrollment period from March 31 to April 15 for an estimated 50,000 policyholders who had not yet arranged new insurance coverage. Under state law, health insurers are required to open their enrollment to policyholders of a defunct carrier for a set period of time and must automatically grant coverage to those policyholders willing to pay the premiums.

headline.main: Judge Says He May Extend Deadline for New Jersey HIP Policyholders

docs.lead_paragraph: Jane Brody's story of her own breast cancer (''Living Proof: Mammograms Are Not Always Enough,'' March 8) omits a critical health problem. She says that ''money should not be a concern that deters women from having regular mammograms.'' But for the millions without health insurance, if the result is positive, what happens next? Who pays for the biopsy, pathology report, radiation, surgery and five years of expensive tamoxifen? What are the ethics of encouraging breast cancer detection when many women have no access to care. We need a tax-based universal access health system. Otherwise, we find the cancer, we tell the woman and we leave her to die. MARVIN THALENBERG Annapolis, Md.

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's hospitals are experiencing a shortage of registered nurses, especially the specialized, highly trained nurses who staff operating rooms, emergency rooms, intensive care units and pediatric wards for high-risk babies. Driven in part by an aging population and the turmoil in managed care, the shortage began a year ago in California, and this year it has touched nearly all acute-care hospitals, where patients go with strokes, heart attacks and major surgery and that employ nearly two-thirds of all registered nurses.

headline.main: Registered Nurses in Short Supply at Hospitals Nationwide

docs.abstract: Nation's hospitals are experiencing shortage of registered nurses, especially specialized, highly trained ones who staff operating and emergency rooms, intensive care units and pediatric wards; shortage, which began year ago in California, has affected nearly all acute-care hospitals that employ nearly two-thirds of all registered nurses, driven in part by aging population and turmoil in managed care; hospitals and nurses' organizations cite many causes of decline; say nurses are growing older and retiring just as baby boom generation approaches age of failing health; say women, who still make up 90 percent of all nurses, have far more and better-paying career choices; note unintended consequences of hospital belt-tightening, with laid-off nurses rebuffing appeals to return to bedside and shifting to new administrative jobs with related companies; chart; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After a wave of corruption investigations swept away many of New York City's longtime labor leaders, a new cast of union leaders is starting to make the city's labor movement more vigorous -- and more combative -- than it has been in decades, labor experts and union officials say. Having been on the defensive for months over corruption, unions are now planning a series of aggressive actions, like mounting a drive to organize 50,000 home health-care workers and demonstrating at Fifth Avenue department stores that use nonunion janitors.

headline.main: After Scandals, New Union Leaders Turn More Aggressive

docs.abstract: Labor experts and union officials say that after wave of corruption swept away many of New York City's long time labor leaders, new cast of union leaders is starting to make city's labor movement more vigorous as well as more combative than it has been in decades; having been on defensive for months over corruption, unions are now planning series of aggressive actions, like mounting drive to organize 50,000 home health care workers; several unions, in effort to increase labor's political clout, have formed new coalition with black and Hispanic politicians that aims to remake state's Democratic party and reshape government priorities (M)
